title: Press freedom under scrutiny as ABC loses challenge to raids
text:
Judge Bromwich said he was not convinced granting the ABC's appeal would not disrupt another court hearing, due to start on October 28, meaning a final ruling could be delayed well into 2020.

Journalists bear the brunt

Rupert Murdoch's News Corp has begun its own High Court challenge to a raid on the Canberra home of political editor Annika Smethurst.

The Senate's environment and communications references committee held hearings on the state of press freedom in Canberra, hearing the raids had caused a "chilling effect" on potential sources considering leaking sensitive information in the public interest.

ABC news director Gaven Morris and News Corp executive Campbell Reid said they would push Attorney-General Christian Porter to explain the status of the two cases, after he ordered that journalists not be prosecuted without his consent.

"We certainly don’t know the status of where our journalists sit within that investigation," Mr Morris told the committee.

"How long are these processes meant to endure without any clarity or any certainty for those journalists and their families living their lives?

"In the end, the impact [of] this has been on journalists but the stories that were told at the beginning of this were in the public’s interest and it’s the public who, we know, are increasingly now tuning into this conversation because they can see that."

Advertisement

Mr Reid said a coalition of media organisations had previously sought to influence draft security legislation, providing alternative structures to better protect journalists.

"It wasn't that we weren't speaking, it was that we weren't being listened to," he said.

"There is now an opportunity to go back and look at those laws, take a breath, fresh set of eyes and say, actually, several of these go too far."

Paul Murphy, the chief executive of the Media, Entertainment and Arts Alliance union, said the raids were limiting the work of reporters.

"A number of our journalist members have told me since the police raids earlier this year that they've lost sources, that they've lost stories because [potential sources] clearly see the nature of those raids as being government agencies sending a message."

Journalist and academic Margaret Simons told MPs better protections for journalists were urgently needed.

"We need something and we need it quickly. We are in crisis," she said.
description: An inquiry has heard press freedom is in crisis in Australia and potential sources are turning away from journalists because of police raids.
